name: Pedro Lemos
body: ![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/21270647/18029180/a07f8c2e-6c67-11e6-8ca2-7c63271ec1b9.png) ### About me My research interests are primarily in semantics for _tense-modal_ languages, the problem of future contingents, (indicative and counterfactual) conditionals, and extends to whatever overlaps between these topics and Metaphysics, Philosophy of Language, Logic, and Formal Semantics. ### Papers, or drafts, or unclear thoughts that might go nowhere * _The Fading Light of Contingency: On Tense, Modals, and Assessment-sensitivity_ (Ph.D. Thesis) * _Diamonds don't shine forever_ * _Conditionals, Hindsight, and Relativist semantics_ * _On Epstein's 'Reflections on temporal and modal logic'_ * _Supertruth-makers_ > A `supervaluations meet truthmakers' sort of thing * _Where is non-classicality in a theory of meaning?_ * _A Turing Machine for Exponential Function_ ### Talks * Conditionals, Retrospective Judgments, and Relative-truth. * Presented in Ninth Principia International Symposium: Possible Worlds and their Applications in Philosophy and the Sciences, 2015, FlorianÃ³polis, 2015. ### Awards * 'Nota 10 Fellowship', 2009 * A one-year fellowship awarded annually by FAPERJ (Rio de Janeiro State funding agency), to a Ph.D./M.A student enrolled in a graduate program ranked 5 or above by CAPES (Brazilian national funding agency) * $4.17 awarded for a full description of a single-tape Turing Machine which computes the exponentiation function f(x,y)=x^y (as advertised in Epstein & Carnielli (2008): _Computability. Computable Functions Logic and the Foundations of Mathematics._ Wadsworth & Brooks/Cole Mathematics Series; p.82) ### Miscellaneous * [https://github.com/jez/tsim](https://github.com/jez/tsim) > An implementation of my Turing Machine for exponentiation, by Jacob Zimmerman
